bug.author: ingambe
bug.summary: [rllib] Problem when specific state size of the environment + Numpy Warning
bug.description:
There is two problems:
When the state has a specific size (210), we have an error, and the actor die A warning message about non-writable array from Numpy (discussed previously on the slack channel: https://ray-distributed.slack.com/archives/CMVUQ22JD/p1602160939157200)
Ray version and other system information (Python version, TensorFlow version, OS): Ray 1.0.0 but also tried with the latest wheel, same issue. Python 3.7.7, also tried on another with python 3.8.3 Pytorch 1.8 Ubuntu 20.04.1 <denchmark-h:h3>Reproduction</denchmark-h>
I've made a gist for this issue: <denchmark-link:https://gist.github.com/ingambe/3ae1a7bfda37da486709c81decd8355e>https://gist.github.com/ingambe/3ae1a7bfda37da486709c81decd8355e</denchmark-link>
It contains a fake environment + a training loop with a custom network (with mask action, useless in this example but used in practice) for PPO. If you modify the size of the state we give to the agent, there is no bug, anything apart from 30 seems to work. You need simply to modify this line here, and put whatever size you want: <denchmark-link:https://gist.github.com/ingambe/3ae1a7bfda37da486709c81decd8355e#file-state_size_problem-py-L95>https://gist.github.com/ingambe/3ae1a7bfda37da486709c81decd8355e#file-state_size_problem-py-L95</denchmark-link>
But a state of size 210 doesn't work (30 * 7, it's a fattened tabular state) It seems to be a problem with Pytorch, but the error message is unclear and hard to trace. Also, there is in the output a small but annoying Numpy warning about non-writable array: (pid=64684) /home/local/IWAS/pierre/anaconda3/envs/JSS_Scratch/lib/python3.7/site-packages/ray/rllib/utils/torch_ops.py:65: UserWarning: The given NumPy array is not writeable, and PyTorch does not support non-writeable tensors. This means you can write to the underlying (supposedly non-writeable) NumPy array using the tensor. You may want to copy the array to protect its data or make it writeable before converting it to a tensor. This type of warning will be suppressed for the rest of this program. (Triggered internally at /opt/conda/conda-bld/pytorch_1595629401553/work/torch/csrc/utils/tensor_numpy.cpp:141.) The complete logs are given as a comment in the gist
I have verified my script runs in a clean environment and reproduces the issue. I have verified the issue also occurs with the latest wheels.

comments.comment:
About the "The given NumPy array is not writeable" warning, I initially thought it's related to numpy arrays created in my environment's custom logic as states to be returned, but further investigating it shows this is not the case, but rather it's referring to the gradients that pass through AsyncGradients and ApplyGradients (head<->workers). I thought this means that the policy isn't training, but it is not the case if the policy weights aren't impacted by the fact the gradients are "not writeable", so it's a question of if they are or not... It seems like this is rooted at the creation of the state tensors which are to be kept immutable anyway. This has nothing to do with the tensors you care to change during training, to the best of my knowledge. Empirically, my training makes good progress even though I get those warnings, so I don't think you should be worried.
